module.name: matrix
module.short: Two, three, four dimensional matrix unit

descr.p: The unit matrix is a unit that provides objects for the common two, three and four dimensional vectors matrixes. These vectors and matrixes are very common in computer graphics and are often implemented from scratch by programmers while every implementation provides exactly the same functionality.

It makes therefore sense to provide this functionality in the runtime library. This eliminates the need for programmers to reinvent the wheel and also allows libraries that use matrix operations to become more compatible.

The matrix unit does not provide n-dimensional matrixes. The functionality needs of a general matrix unit varies from application to application; one can think of reduced memory usage tricks for matrixes that only have data around the diagonal etc., desire for parallelization etc. etc. It is believed that programmers that do use n-dimensional matrices would not necessarily benfit from such a unit in the runtime library.

ul.li: Provide common dimensions, two three and four.
Provide multiple floating point precisions, single, double, extended.
Simple trivial binary representation; it is possible to typecast vectors into other implementations that use the same trivial representation.
No dynamic memory management in the background. It must be possible to write expressions like matrix A * B * C without worrying about memory management.
Class object model is ruled out. The objects object model, without virtual methods, is suitable.
Operator overloading is a good way to allow programmers to write matrix expressions.
3 dimensions * 3 precision means 9 vector and 9 matrix objects. Macro's have been used in the source to take care of this.

element.name: Tvector2_single_data
element.short: Internal data of Tvector2_single
element.descr: This is the vector internal data for a vector. It uses a simple array structure so data from other libraries that define their own vector type as a simple array structure can simply be moved to and from this data, or typecasted into it. As this is the only field in the object, the object itself can be used just as fine for typecasting purposes etc.

element.name: Tvector2_single.length
element.short: Calculates the length of the vector.
element.descr: Calculate the length of the vector: length=sqrt(data[0]**2+data[1]**2). Try to use squared_length if you are able to, as it is faster.

element.name: Tvector2_double.length
element.short: Calculates the length of the vector.
element.descr: Calculate the length of the vector: length=sqrt(data[0]**2+data[1]**2). Try to use squared_length if you are able to, as it is faster.

element.short: Calculates the length of the vector.
element.descr: Calculate the length of the vector: length=sqrt(data[0]**2+data[1]**2). Try to use squared_length if you are able to, as it is faster.

element.descr: Calculate the length of the vector: length=sqrt(data[0]**2+data[1]**2+data[2]**2). Try to use squared_length if you are able to, as it is faster.

element.name: Tvector2_single.squared_length
element.short: Calculates the squared length of the vector.
element.descr: Calculate the squared length of the vector: squared_length=data[0]**2+data[1]**2.

element.descr: Calculate the squared length of the vector: squared_length=data[0]**2+data[1]**2.

element.name: Tmatrix2_single.init_identity
element.short: Initializes the matrix and sets its elements to the identity matrix.
element.descr: Initializes the matrix and sets its elements to the identity matrix, that is, elements to 1 on the left-upper to right-lower diagonal, the rest zero.

element.name: Tmatrix2_single.init
element.short: Initializes the matrix, setting its elements to the values passed to the constructor.
element.descr: Initializes the matrix, setting its elements to the values passed to the constructor. The order of the values is left to right, then top to bottom.

element.short: Initializes the matrix, setting its elements to the values passed to the constructor.
element.descr: Initializes the matrix, setting its elements to the values passed to the constructor. The order of the values is left to right, then top to bottom.

element.name: Tmatrix2_single.get_row
element.short: Returns the r-th row of the matrix as vector.
element.descr: Returns the r-th row of the matrix as vector. The row numbering starts at 0.

element.name: Tmatrix2_double.get_row
element.short: Returns the r-th row of the matrix as vector.
element.descr: Returns the r-th row of the matrix as vector. The row numbering starts at 0.

element.name: Tmatrix2_single.inverse
element.short: Calculates the inverse of the matrix.
element.descr: Tmatrix2_single.inverse returns a new matrix that is the inverse of the matrix. You must pass the determinant of the matrix as parameter.

element.name: Tmatrix2_double.inverse
element.short: Calculates the inverse of the matrix.
element.descr: Tmatrix2_double.inverse returns a new matrix that is the inverse of the matrix. You must pass the determinant of the matrix as parameter.

element.short: Calculates the inverse of the matrix.
element.descr: Tmatrix2_extended.inverse returns a new matrix that is the inverse of the matrix. You must pass the determinant of the matrix as parameter.

element.name: Tmatrix2_single.transpose
element.short: Returns the transposition of the matrix.
element.descr: Tmatrix2_single.transpose returns a new matrix that is the transposition of the matrix, that is, the matrix with the x and y coordinates of the values swapped.

element.name: Tmatrix2_double.transpose
element.short: Returns the transposition of the matrix.
element.descr: Tmatrix2_double.transpose returns a new matrix that is the transposition of the matrix, that is, the matrix with the x and y coordinates of the values swapped.

element.name: operator :=(Tvector2_single): Tvector2_double
element.short: Allow assignment of single precision vector to double precision vector
element.descr: This operator allows you to use a vector with single precision values wherever a double precision vector is expected.

element.name: operator :=(Tvector2_single): Tvector2_extended
element.short: Allow assignment of single precision vector to extended precision vector
element.descr: This operator allows you to use a vector with single precision values wherever an extended precision vector is expected.

element.name: operator :=(Tvector2_double): Tvector2_single
element.short: Allow assignment of double precision vector to single precision vector
element.descr: This operator allows you to use a vector with double precision values wherever a single precision vector is expected, at the cost of loosing some precision.

element.name: operator :=(Tvector2_double): Tvector2_extended
element.short: Allow assignment of double precision vector to extended precision vector
element.descr: This operator allows you to use a vector with double precision values wherever an extended precision vector is expected.

element.name: operator :=(Tvector2_extended): Tvector2_single
element.short: Allow assignment of extended precision vector to single precision vector
element.descr: This operator allows you to use a vector with extended precision values wherever a single precision vector is expected, at the cost of loosing some precision.

element.name: operator :=(Tvector2_extended): Tvector2_double
element.short: Allow assignment of extended precision vector to double precision vector
element.descr: This operator allows you to use a vector with extended precision values wherever a double precision vector is expected, at the cost of loosing some precision.

element.name: operator :=(Tvector2_single): Tvector3_single
element.short: Allow assignment of two-dimensional single precision vector to three-dimensional single precision vector
element.descr: This operator allows you to use a two-dimensional vector with single precision values wherever a three-dimensional vector with single precision is expected. The third dimension is set to 0.0.

element.name: operator :=(Tvector2_single): Tvector3_double
element.short: Allow assignment of two-dimensional single precision vector to three-dimensional double precision vector
element.descr: This operator allows you to use a two-dimensional vector with single precision values wherever a three-dimensional vector with double precision is expected. The third dimension is set to 0.0.

element.descr: This operator allows you to use a two-dimensional vector with single precision values wherever a three-dimensional vector with extended precision is expected. The third dimension is set to 0.0.

element.name: operator :=(Tvector2_double): Tvector3_single
element.short: Allow assignment of two-dimensional double precision vector to three-dimensional single precision vector
element.descr: This operator allows you to use a two-dimensional vector with double precision values wherever a three-dimensional vector with single precision is expected. Some accuracy is lost because of the conversion and the third dimension is set to 0.0.

element.short: Allow assignment of four-dimensional extended precision vector to two-dimensional single precision vector
element.descr: This operator allows you to use a four-dimensional vector with extended precision values wherever a two-dimensional vector with single precision is expected. The third and fourth dimensions are thrown away and some accuracy is los because of the conversion.
